ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about many different aspects of energy (social, geoengineering, technical aspect, financial).

We learned a lot about a range of different subjects in energy including energy markets, energy production, energy consumption, and almost any topic relating to energy. We also did two research projects on a country of our choice so we got to learn about the energy consumption of any country we were interested in or had a connection to.

Overview of the state of world energy.  My main takeaways from this course were more skills-based, such as researching a country's energy plan, finding energy stats and sources, and writing a research essay about a country's 2030 and 2050 energy plans.
Variety of topics dealing with energy and climate science (energy sectors, energy markets, net-zero goals, environmental justice, geoengineering, etc.)
A broad overview of topics, mainly scientific and economic, related to energy over the world.
I learned more about energy markets, global trends in energy usage, and strategies to reduce and mitigate greenhouse gas emissions.
Learned a lot about energy issues facing different parts of the world, different types of energy, and global solutions (or attempts at solutions) to climate change.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: excellent professor!, interesting readings, very engaging in-class discussion, and interesting final project topic

This course was nice in that it was really a case of however much you put in you get out. The work load wasn't too bad and the format Dr. Oristaglio had (discussion first lecture last) helped with staying engaged during class. I think a little more communication about when discussion posts were needed or not would be helpful.

Strengths: I liked the four graded assignments we did (land metric area of an energy source, paper on a country of our choice's 2030 energy plan, market electricity bidding exercise, and presentation on a country of our choice's potential for Net Zero by 2050).  Great professor. 
Weaknesses: The course had quite a bit of overlap with Renewable Energy, so sometimes I felt like I wasn't learning much new information.

Strengths: Professor Oristaglio is clearly passionate about the subject and I found all of the topics to be very interesting.
Weaknesses: Sometimes it would have been nice for additional discussion about the topics.
I think Professor Oristaglio is amazingly clear about his expectations in the sense that does not intimidate students and encourage risk-taking.
I liked our discussions, and think that as discussion section would be a nice addition to the class.

Strengths: because it's an energy studies class, everyone there is super interested in the material and clearly cares! material is so relevant and discussions were really fruitful. Also none of the assignments felt pointless, I learned something different from each one. 

Weaknesses: sometimes the powerpoints in class were really long and with a lot of text, so it was hard to keep up/stay engaged

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely!
If you are interested in learning about all things energy (science, policy, etc.) then this is a perfect class for you!

Would recommend this course as an easy, low workload credit.  The content takeaways of this course weren't super clear to me, but it was cool to see the final product of our assignments.  I liked having the chance to meet other Energy Studies students.
Yes, it is a great Energy Studies course that allows you to explore a multitude of topics.
Yes, it is very digestible, low-stress but high-effort.

Yes; this course provided a well-rounded overview of energy today. I also enjoyed the group projectsnot only were they helpful to learn the subject matter, they introduced me to other Energy Studies students. Especially after a year on Zoom, it was nice to meet people with common interests!
yes!! you learn a lot and can really get as much out of it as you put into it.
